title: 'Beautiful chaos': Nationals come out ahead in bizarre – and hugely consequential – inning
text:
USA TODAY

HOUSTON – An unfortunate rules interpretation seemed destined to unravel the Washington Nationals’ season as it teetered on the game’s biggest stage.

Instead, it revealed an awful lot about how they got here in the first place.

For some 15 minutes Tuesday night, the Nationals experienced a gamut of emotions during a pivotal seventh-inning sequence in Game 6 of the World Series – anger, confusion, elation, camaraderie and perhaps above all an esprit de corps that has defined a season of living dangerously.

They emerged from it all to discover baseball’s ultimate party awaiting them – Game 7 of the World Series, nine more innings to determine baseball’s champion.

And should the Washington Nationals vanquish the Houston Astros on Wednesday night and claim the first title in franchise history, they may yet look back on Tuesday’s theatrics and shake their head in amazement.

Their starting shortstop, screaming at Major League Baseball’s Chief Baseball Officer.

Their franchise pitcher, hurriedly warming up to save the day barely 48 hours after he could not lift his pitching arm.

Their manager, enraged by said questionable call exploding from the dugout, putting spin moves on his own bench coach and earning the first World Series ejection for a skipper since 1996.

And their MVP candidate, stepping coolly into the fray to hammer a baseball 353 feet and render so much of the above gloriously moot.

“It was beautiful chaos,” closer Sean Doolittle said after recording the final two outs of an unforgettable 7-2 victory that vaulted the Nationals into the game of their lives on Wednesday night.

GAME 6:Strasburg brilliant as Nationals overcome deficit, controversy

BAT FLIPS(?): Bregman and Soto try to show each other up

For nearly 10 minutes, though, it was just chaos – ugly, at times.

It all started when shortstop Trea Turner was ruled out by plate umpire Sam Holbrook for interfering with first baseman Yuli Gurriel’s ability to catch a throw from catcher Robinson Chirinos after Turner chopped a ball in front of the plate.

Know this: Rule 5.09(a) is a judgment call, one that the umpires’ union was quick to defend on social media and one that MLB’s Chief Baseball Officer, Joe Torre, ruled was correct in a postgame press conference.

“Sam Holbrook made the call. It was the right call,” Torre said, before expending a couple hundred words noting why Nationals manager Dave Martinez was so upset about it.

Sure, Turner technically ran “inside (to the left of) the foul line,” impeding Gurriel’s ability to receive the throw, as the rule states.

Yet, to the fellows on the field playing the game, it comes down to the letter vs. the spirit of the law, and the prevailing notion that so long as the baserunner maintains a straight line, he is within that spirit.

Turner certainly felt that way after bursting from the batter’s box in the seventh inning of the biggest game of his life.

“What. Else. Do. You. Do?” Turner asked. “The batter’s box is in fair territory. First base is in fair territory. I swung, I ran a straight line, I got hit with the ball. I’m out.

"I don’t understand it. I could understand it if I veered one way or another. I didn’t. I don’t know.”

With Yan Gomes running from first on the play, the Nationals were prepared for second and third, nobody out, and their best 1-2 punch – Anthony Rendon and Juan Soto – due up.

Instead, Turner was ruled out, Gomes returned to first, and the Nationals’ 3-2 lead looked like it might stay right there – with nine more outs to record against the devastating Astros.

“It was just a lot of momentum taken away in that play,” says Turner, “and I didn’t feel like there was a reason for it.”

After Martinez requested a “rule check” replay review – which lasted 4 minutes, 32 seconds and resolved nothing – Turner, back in the Nationals’ dugout, spotted Torre seated in the first few rows, as is common for postseason games.

He couldn’t resist, accusing the grand poohbah of all on-field activity of hiding during a pivotal moment of the World Series.

“I’ll probably get in trouble for all this,” says Turner, “but Joe Torre’s in charge of the umpires and I think if we want clarification, we should do everything we possibly can to get the calls on the field right. And if it’s in the rules that I did the wrong thing, so be it.

“But this stage is too big, too important to a lot of people to have every avenue not (exhausted) to get everything as right as possible and let the players decide the outcome.”

As it unfolded, Rendon was in the dugout getting ready to hit, and befitting perhaps the chillest man in baseball, he was surprised but not startled.

“Once they showed the replay on the big screen, then I was like, ‘Oh,’” he said. “I was a little bit more surprised than I guess I had anticipated.”

As the Nationals raged, and reliever Will Harris – perfect to this point in the postseason – came on, ailing ace Max Scherzer loosened in the Nationals bullpen.

The plan: He’d come on in a tie game or to protect a one-run lead. And the jarring tones of the bullpen phone kept cutting through the noise generated by the Minute Maid Park crowd of 43,384.

“The last three innings,” says Doolittle, “there were a lot of phone calls.”

Rendon put the stakes aside and focused.

“You can't let any outside elements get into the game,” he says. “No matter if it's the crowd. You've got 40,000 people cheering against you. No one is going to feel sorry for you. They're going to expect you to go out there and just perform as best as you can, and they're going to expect the best out of you.”

As he has so many times this season, Rendon gave the Nationals just that.

He hammered a Harris cutter into the left field seats, pushing the Nationals’ lead to 5-2.

The controversial call? Not forgotten, but happily minimized.

Scherzer? Just 48 hours after he could not lift his right arm due to nerve irritation in his neck, he happily sat down, ready to save himself for Game 7.

“You go from thinking you have second and third and nobody out with the middle of the order come up, it’s obviously deflating and upsetting, whether it was the right call or not,” says first baseman Ryan Zimmerman. “To do what Tony did and to keep fighting and get a couple runs that inning was huge. To be able to calm down right there and get a hit is enormous.”

Says Turner: “In sports in general, I don’t think you ever want it to hinge on anything other than the players. If the rule’s the rule, then so be it. But you want the players to have an outcome. And I’m just glad I don’t think it had an effect afterward.

“It makes it a lot easier to move on, obviously, when someone hits a two-run homer.”

Well, sort of.

Martinez, understandably enraged at Holbrook’s call, protested vociferously and was granted a long leash, staying in the game even after the replay review.

Yet after Rendon’s homer, between innings, Martinez pushed forth from the dugout, railing at Holbrook and crew chief Gary Cederstrom. Bench coach Chip Hale held him back. Martinez pushed forward.

Martinez was ejected. And kept bull-rushing.

“We gotta work on Chip. Chip’s got to get in the weight room,” says Doolittle. “He looked like he was ready to play D-end, man, that he was going to get to the quarterback no matter what.”

Yet to the Nationals, Martinez’s tirade meant the world.

“We were playing in the World Series and had a lead, so we had all the motivation we could get,” says Turner. “But I love it. I’m a big fan. I think the passion shows, from the whole bench, from that whole situation. I love it.”

That it came barely six weeks after Martinez was hospitalized and underwent a heart procedure, missing three games in the midst of the club’s wild-card push, only made his players all the more slack-jawed.

The outburst also came after a Game 5 in which home plate umpire Lance Barksdale’s strike zone was, shall we say, creative.

Martinez on down to the players stuck hard to the talking points of not blaming the umpires. But still.

“Objectively, a couple close ones didn’t go our way,” says Doolittle. “And for him to have the team’s back – it fired me up, Max was fired up. I thought it was good.”

Rendon later added a two-run double, setting up this winner-take-all match that seemed destined once the Nationals snagged Game 1 here eight days ago.

Scherzer started Game 1, and now he’ll start Game 7, with everything at stake.

“I’m just glad,” says Turner, “we gave him a chance to throw tomorrow.”

A chance no judgment call can take away.
description: The Nationals had a budding rally temporarily quashed by a controversial rules interpretation, but fought through the chaos to come out ahead.
